qas.question: What are some examples of non-bilaterian animals?
What are animals whose body plans display bilateral symmetry called?
Animals in what group are thought to form a monophyletic group?

context: Traditional morphological and modern molecular phylogenetic analysis have both recognized a major evolutionary transition from "non-bilaterian" animals, which are those lacking a bilaterally symmetric body plan (<a0_0>Porifera, Ctenophora, Cnidaria and Placozoa<a0_0/>), to "<a1_0>bilaterian<a1_0/>" animals (Bilateria) whose body plans display bilateral symmetry. The latter are further classified based on a major division between Deuterostomes and Protostomes. The relationships among non-bilaterian animals are disputed, but all <a2_0>bilaterian<a2_0/> animals are thought to form a monophyletic group.
